item.title: 007 First Light Release Date Delayed to May
item.content:encoded:
Developer and publisher IO Interactive has announced that upcoming spy adventure 007 First Light has been delayed beyond its originally-announced release date.

In a message on social media, the studio reveals that 007 First Light will now be released on May 27th next year, which represents a delay of roughly two months. IO says the game is its "most ambitious project to date", and that the delay will allow the devs to ensure the project is up to snuff when it's released.

Despite the delay, it sounds like development on 007 First Light is going smoothly; IO Interactive says the game is "fully playable from beginning to end", so all that needs to be done now is work to "further polish and refine the experience".

If you're awaiting more information about 007 First Light, IO Interactive says it'll share more about the project early next year, so you won't have to wait too long. Hopefully, that'll take the sting out of the tail of this delay.

If you're unfamiliar, 007 First Light is an upcoming stealth-action game from IO Interactive, the creator of the Hitman franchise. 

Revealed earlier this year, the game will seemingly operate along similar lines to the studio's flagship series, placing protagonist James Bond in a series of exotic locales as he sneaks and bluffs his way past the locals in an attempt to "expose a deep conspiracy".

007 First Light takes place towards the beginning of Bond's career; despite the game's name, Bond hasn't yet earned his "00" license to kill, so you'll witness how he does so over the course of First Light's narrative.

007 First Light is now slated for release on May 27th next year. When it arrives, you'll be able to pick it up on PC, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and Nintendo Switch 2. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Buckshot Roulette Sales Hit 8m, Console Ports Delayed to 2026
item.content:encoded:
Developer Mike Klubnika and publisher Critical Reflex have revealed that unsettling indie horror game Buckshot Roulette has managed to pass another huge sales milestone, and they've provided an update on the game's console ports as well.

As revealed on Steam, Buckshot Roulette has reached a staggering eight million copies sold since launching back in 2023. Given that it's currently only available via Steam or Itch.io, that's a very impressive milestone indeed, putting the game ahead of heavy hitters like Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, not to mention the entire Octopath series.

Klubnika and Critical Reflex describe the new milestone as "insane", emphasizing that there are "whole countries with fewer citizens" than the total count of Buckshot Roulette players. Again, it's worth remembering that the game isn't available on any kind of subscription service and never has been, so this really is sales rather than just players.

In the Steam post, Klubnika and Critical Reflex also provide an update on the console versions of Buckshot Roulette, which were originally due to arrive this year. However, due to "some technical difficulties, mostly because of the engine", the game will be arriving on consoles next year.

Additionally, over the course of the next year or so, you can look forward to new Buckshot Roulette merchandise hitting the shelves, as well as a physical release for the game's soundtrack in case you want to relive your days trying not to shoot yourself in the face in a grimy basement.

In case you're unfamiliar, Buckshot Roulette is an indie horror game that combines Inscryption-style atmosphere with Russian roulette gameplay mechanics. As you've probably surmised from the title, the idea is to "play Russian roulette with a 12-gauge", and whether you walk away with your life or not is up to fate.

Buckshot Roulette is just one of the unnerving horror games available as part of publisher Critical Reflex's slate; it joins the likes of Mouthwashing and No, I'm Not a Human, along with experimental fare like How Fish Is Made and Carimara.

You can check out Buckshot Roulette right now on PC via Steam and Itch.io, and it's slated to come to consoles next year as well. Stay tuned for more.
